articles.headline: Accounting Error May Not Derail Deal, but Ex-Director Bails Early Anyway
articles.snippet: Diamond Resorts’ stock has held up despite a delayed earnings report, because it’s about to be bought. So why did an ex-director cash in so much stock?
articles.abstract: Diamond Resorts’ stock has held up despite a delayed earnings report, because it’s about to be bought. So why did an ex-director cash in so much stock?
articles.lead_paragraph: When a company delays the release of its financial results because of an accounting error, spooked investors typically flee, and shares plummet.

articles.headline: How Dell Raised $67 Billion for the Biggest Tech Deal Ever
articles.snippet: It took months of complicated financial maneuvering at a tumultuous time in the markets to raise money for the industry’s largest takeover ever.
articles.abstract: It took months of complicated financial maneuvering at a tumultuous time in the markets to raise money for the industry’s largest takeover ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — When Dell first announced its $67 billion deal to buy the fellow technology giant EMC last year, the transaction faced no small amount of skepticism — in large part because it was simply so expensive.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Moment in Convention Glare Shakes Up Khans’ American Life
articles.snippet: How Khizr and Ghazala Khan, parents of a soldier killed in Iraq, came to challenge Donald J. Trump and reshape a presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: How Khizr and Ghazala Khan, parents of a soldier killed in Iraq, came to challenge Donald J. Trump and reshape a presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six minutes and one second. That was all it took for the 66 years of Khizr Khan’s life to become an American moment.
articles.byline: By N. R. Kleinfield, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Donald Trump Endorses Paul Ryan and John McCain in Bid for G.O.P. Unity
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, who had caused a rift by withholding support for Mr. Ryan, also called for the re-election of Senator Kelly Ayotte as he sought to move past a tumultuous week.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, who had caused a rift by withholding support for Mr. Ryan, also called for the re-election of Senator Kelly Ayotte as he sought to move past a tumultuous week.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Donald J. Trump belatedly endorsed the re-elections of Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Senators John McCain and Kelly Ayotte on Friday, moving to heal a deepening rift within the Republican Party touched off by Mr. Trump’s feud with the parents of a slain American soldier.

articles.headline: A Surreal Life on the Precipice in Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: Swimming pools pop up in slums, horses graze in schoolhouses, and public housing tenants pay negative rent on an island whose government has effectively gone broke.
articles.abstract: Swimming pools pop up in slums, horses graze in schoolhouses, and public housing tenants pay negative rent on an island whose government has effectively gone broke.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s official: America now has a failed state within its borders, just the way Europe has Greece.

articles.headline: From Syrian Rubble to German Concert Halls With a Piano, a Mission and Survivor’s Guilt
articles.snippet: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
articles.abstract: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WIESBADEN, Germany — The pianist starts his show abruptly, with a wail. The words and music are Arabic, but the pain is clear in any language.

articles.headline: We’re in a Low-Growth World. How Did We Get Here?
articles.snippet: Economic growth in advanced nations has been weaker for longer than it has been in most people’s lifetimes.
articles.abstract: Economic growth in advanced nations has been weaker for longer than it has been in most people’s lifetimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: One central fact about the global economy lurks just beneath the year’s remarkable headlines: Economic growth in advanced nations has been weaker for longer than it has been in the lifetime of most people on earth.

articles.headline: Military Success in Syria Gives Putin Upper Hand in U.S. Proxy War
articles.snippet: Russia has not only avoided a quagmire in Syria, its successes on the battlefield against C.I.A.-backed rebels have given it new leverage in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Russia has not only avoided a quagmire in Syria, its successes on the battlefield against C.I.A.-backed rebels have given it new leverage in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Syrian military was foundering last year, with thousands of rebel fighters pushing into areas of the country long considered to be government strongholds. The rebel offensive was aided by powerful tank-destroying missiles supplied by the Central Intelligence Agency and Saudi Arabia.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Anne Barnard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: As Donald Trump Incites Feuds, Other G.O.P. Candidates Flee His Shadow
articles.snippet: Some Republican strategists are prepared to create ads that concede the White House to Hillary Clinton and urge voters to support down-ballot candidates who would keep the party in charge of Congress.
articles.abstract: Some Republican strategists are prepared to create ads that concede the White House to Hillary Clinton and urge voters to support down-ballot candidates who would keep the party in charge of Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a disastrous week of feuds and plummeting poll numbers, Republican leaders have concluded that Donald J. Trump is a threat to the party’s fortunes and have begun discussing how soon their endangered candidates should explicitly distance themselves from the presidential nominee.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: How Think Tanks Amplify Corporate America’s Influence
articles.snippet: Think tanks are seen as independent, but their scholars often push donors’ agendas, amplifying a culture of corporate influence in Washington.
articles.abstract: Think tanks are seen as independent, but their scholars often push donors’ agendas, amplifying a culture of corporate influence in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Lennar Corporation, one of the nation’s largest home builders, pushed ahead with an $8 billion plan to revitalize a barren swath of San Francisco, it found a trusted voice to vouch for its work: the Brookings Institution, the most prestigious think tank in the world.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Brooke Williams

articles.headline: Mike Pence’s Response to H.I.V. Outbreak: Prayer, Then a Change of Heart
articles.snippet: In the face of a growing epidemic, Mr. Pence put aside his own moral opposition to giving syringes to drug users to allow a needle exchange program.
articles.abstract: In the face of a growing epidemic, Mr. Pence put aside his own moral opposition to giving syringes to drug users to allow a needle exchange program.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Ind. — On the evening of March 24, 2015, Sheriff Dan McClain got an unexpected voice mail: “This is Gov. Mike Pence calling. I would welcome the opportunity to get your counsel on what’s going on in Scott County.”

articles.headline: Election Shows Many South Africans Losing Faith in ‘Pompous’ A.N.C.
articles.snippet: Black, middle-class voters appeared more concerned with mundane matters like good governance and taxes than with the party’s heroic liberation past.
articles.abstract: Black, middle-class voters appeared more concerned with mundane matters like good governance and taxes than with the party’s heroic liberation past.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANTELLE, South Africa — A week before South Africa’s local elections on Wednesday, the Zithas held a family meeting inside their entertainment room to decide how to vote. Loyal backers of the African National Congress in every election since the end of apartheid, the family decided it was time for a change.

articles.headline: How an Iranian’s Spy Saga Ends, 6 Years Later: He’s Executed
articles.snippet: In 2010, Shahram Amiri, a scientist, claimed on YouTube that the C.I.A. had kidnapped him. A subsequent video changed the narrative. Missing his son, he returned to Iran and disappeared.
articles.abstract: In 2010, Shahram Amiri, a scientist, claimed on YouTube that the C.I.A. had kidnapped him. A subsequent video changed the narrative. Missing his son, he returned to Iran and disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Shahram Amiri emerged from the shadows into the spotlight six years ago, he was a young Iranian scientist who suddenly appeared on YouTube from a safe house, telling a bizarre story of having been kidnapped by the Central Intelligence Agency.

articles.headline: ‘This Is Your Brain on Drugs,’ Tweaked for Today’s Parents
articles.snippet: Children of the 1980s will remember the sizzling egg equated to a brain on drugs. Its coming back helps those same people talk to their own children.
articles.abstract: Children of the 1980s will remember the sizzling egg equated to a brain on drugs. Its coming back helps those same people talk to their own children.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a generation of commercial-watching adolescents, it was an indelible image: an egg, sizzling in a frying pan, representing “your brain on drugs.” It was a straightforward message, and the ad’s final line — “Any questions?” — asked as the egg white clouded and cooked, was strictly rhetorical.

articles.headline: How to Give Rural America Broadband? Look to the Early 1900s
articles.snippet: To provide high-speed internet to remote areas, local power companies are borrowing techniques that were used to electrify towns in the United States nearly a century ago.
articles.abstract: To provide high-speed internet to remote areas, local power companies are borrowing techniques that were used to electrify towns in the United States nearly a century ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZENA, Okla. — From the sofa in his living room, Clinton Creason can see the electric pole outside that his father staked 70 years ago to bring power to this remote area of hilly cattle pastures.

articles.headline: Once Taunted by Steve Jobs, Companies Are Now Big Customers of Apple
articles.snippet: Corporations are turning to Apple’s products for their tight-knit hardware and software, advanced security and intuitive interfaces.
articles.abstract: Corporations are turning to Apple’s products for their tight-knit hardware and software, advanced security and intuitive interfaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the primordial days of computing, IBM machines were so common inside corporations that there was a running joke in the industry: Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM.

articles.headline: After Ailes and Cosby, a Moment for More Women to Speak Up
articles.snippet: High-profile accusations have drawn new attention to sexual harassment and assault, but the risks of reporting incidents still discourage women from coming forward.
articles.abstract: High-profile accusations have drawn new attention to sexual harassment and assault, but the risks of reporting incidents still discourage women from coming forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1991, an obscure law professor named Anita Hill pushed the issue of sexual harassment into the public consciousness when she accused her former boss, the Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas, of having repeatedly made lewd overtures toward her.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Trump Is Testing the Norms of Objectivity in Journalism
articles.snippet: As Donald J. Trump continues his stream of outrageous and disquieting statements, journalists must grapple with how to cover him — and if, or when, to abandon the rules of traditional reporting.
articles.abstract: As Donald J. Trump continues his stream of outrageous and disquieting statements, journalists must grapple with how to cover him — and if, or when, to abandon the rules of traditional reporting.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a working journalist and you believe that Donald J. Trump is a demagogue playing to the nation’s worst racist and nationalistic tendencies, that he cozies up to anti-American dictators and that he would be dangerous with control of the United States nuclear codes, how the heck are you supposed to cover him?

articles.headline: At 82, Emperor Akihito of Japan Wants to Retire. Will Japan Let Him?
articles.snippet: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.
articles.abstract: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese have acknowledged that their emperor is not a god and he has been stripped of all political power, but the nation still views its monarch as so central to the sense of identity that he is not permitted to resign.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Adopts G.O.P. Tax Cuts, but Balks at Trade Pacts
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump sought to move beyond a week of turmoil, turning his attention to the economy with a speech in which he cast himself as a president who could create new jobs.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump sought to move beyond a week of turmoil, turning his attention to the economy with a speech in which he cast himself as a president who could create new jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump sought on Monday to move beyond a week of turmoil, using a major policy address to cast himself as a president who could bring new jobs and prosperity and warning that his rival, Hillary Clinton, would be a steward of stagnation.
articles.byline: By Neil Irwin and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Walmart Rewrites Its E-Commerce Strategy With $3.3 Billion Deal for Jet.com
articles.snippet: The acquisition of Jet, the largest deal ever for an e-commerce company, is intended to help both companies compete with Amazon.
articles.abstract: The acquisition of Jet, the largest deal ever for an e-commerce company, is intended to help both companies compete with Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Traditional retailers have spent more than a decade and billions of dollars trying to transform their brick-and-mortar businesses for the online shopper. Yet Amazon and other digital upstarts continue to lap them.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Rachel Abrams
